intro: Lappula texana var. genuina, commonly known as the Texas lappula, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States. It belongs to the family Chenopodiaceae and is characterized by its small, greenish-yellow flowers and hairy leaves. The plant typically grows in arid or semi-arid environments, thriving in sandy or gravelly soils. It has a low-growing habit with upright flowering stems that produce clusters of tiny blooms. The species is adapted to withstand drought and high temperatures, making it a resilient plant in its native habitat.
